sourceDesc.ab:
Vocabulary collected on: 2017-08-07 at:
12 Wohlebengasse
Austrian Academy of Sciences Vienna Austria

Content was recorded using Translation-based elicitation using a list of desired vocab terms and phrases English and/or Spanish; and Contextual elicitations in which the speaker gave examples of the elicited terms in various sentence contexts.

taxonomy.desc: Typology of linguistic speech events captured in recordings as per: Himmelmann (1998). aka Typology of "naturalness".

category.catDesc: Observed communicative event: the extent of external interference is limited to the knowledge of the speakers that the speech is being recorded or observed.

Staged communicative event: speech events realized for the purpose of recording (i.e. elicited speech). Events are not really being realized for the purpose of communication but for the benefit of the investigator.
Staged-Topical: Prompt to speak freely about topic
Staged-Stimuli: events based on stimuli to be described in speakers own words
Elicitation: speech act for the sole purpose of linguistic investigation. (A new type of speech event for most communities).
Contextualizing elicitation: where native speakers are asked to provide contexts for a item or construction as prompted by the investigator.
Translation-based elicitation: native speaker asked to translate item from second language
Judgement: where native speakers are asked to judge the acceptibility of a given construction based on any aspect of language, e.g. grammar, etc.

body.p:
too (as in “too big”-size) (demasiado) ka'nu /
ka'nu nchu'a :
Stiki ncha'i ka'nu nchu'a kui
The black bull is too big. El toro negro es demadiado grande. black bull toro negro too big demasiado grande is es
in (a language) (as in “say it in mixtec”) nu: nu sa'a savi

Koo ixi :
to be bald ser calvo
Chaa ntsanu
ka , koo ka ixi xini ra
The old man's head is bald. La cabeza del anciano es calva. the old man el anciano his head is bald su cabeza es calva

vixi :
funny chiste
Vilu yo'o vixi nchu'a
This cat is really funny. Este gato es mu chiste. cat gato this este funny chiste is very funny es muy chiste

spanGrp.span: this should probably be "Ntavi ini" ("inia" is inflected for 3sg)
should this be "ini"? "inu" seems like it should be 2nd person but the use of 1sg possesive seems to be speaking about the friend. Unless it is saying "you are very kind my friend".
Tisu gave the gloss form as "kini inia" but should it be "kini ini" and the -a is used when inflected?
The people that arrived in town are mean.
La gente que llegan en el pueblo son tacaños.
this is not inflected for person because the person is stated explicitly (kue nivi)/
this also is not inflected (for person) and appears to be present tense (as the past would be "nikitsaa"). Also is this arrive or begin? (i.e. 'the founders of the town')?
Let's eat this tortilla, it's good!
I hear what the people are saying
I hear what the people (have been?) saying
Oigo lo que dice la gente

body.p:
Va'a kita'an inu :
to get along with someone Should "inu" be "ini"? llevarse bien con alguien
Va'a kita'an ini yu tsi ñani yu
I get along well with my brother. Me llevo bien con mi hermano. I get along well with Make "tsi" as a collocate, not part of the lemma llevo bien con my brother mi hermano

spanGrp.span: They will stop and we'll eat tortillas.
Van a parar y vamos a comer tortillas.
Is this "Kunchatu na katso staa" (They will stop and we will eat tortillas) or "Kunchatu nakatso staa"? (Let's stop and eat tortillas)

body.p:
Kava /
ntachiko
to turn girar to turn around darse vuelta
Ntanchiko kitsu ve'e .
? ? I turned around me di vuelta ? ? home casa

spanGrp.span: collocate (the street); should this be "kua'a ya'a" or is this correct? (or does it vary like "kuanu'u" ~"kua'a nu'u")
check on how to spell import words form Spanish with [h]
should this be "ka'no"? (1pl. as in"katso"?) or should "na" be "ña" and the verb "ka'nu"?
where is the object of the sentence?

body.p:
¿ Nixi nania ?
[á]
What's her name? ¿Cómo se llama ella?

spanGrp.span: is this inflected for person? I have "xiko" as the gloss form of 'to sell'. Should it be spelled "xíkui"?
